creditline: Gift of funds from the Decorative Arts Council with proceeds from the 2008 Antiques Show and Sale
description: knife with grey metal blade with gold inlay of five organic plantlike forms on one side of blade; top of short handle has hexagonal body with alternating grey and yellow metal incised panels; end of handle has piece of red coral left in its organic shape
medium: Coral, brass, niello, silver, iron, gold
text: This preciously decorated and extremely rare coral cutlery set from the late 1500s would have been only used on extraordinary occasions, such as a wedding, a knighting or a state visit. In the late Renaissance, the guests would typically bring their own cutlery to formal dinners. An expensively decorated cutlery set would have elicited the host's and other guests' admiration. Besides, coral was believed to be an antidote against poison. Therefore, in the view of its time this set of cutlery would have offered its bearer special protection during a meal at the table of a rival family or of an untrustworthy foreign ruler.
title: Knife, from a two-piece cutlery set
